<th>I got my new UN65JS8500 last Tuesday after I accidentaly broke my XBR55X850A
column2: well accidents happens.</th>
Samsung's new screen panels are called SUHD.

column1: The JS8500 includes the One Connect Mini as oppose to the 9000 series which include the One Connect Box with more input options and future proof of the hardware.
<td>Also this set has a LED Edge-Lit backlight display as his more expensive brother the JS9000
column2: only

column1: the JS9500 has a Full Arrange Local Dimming capabilities that will have superior HDR performance.
<td>And last but not least is the obvious
column2: is not curved but Samsung was extremely wise to keep the flat version only to the US market
column3: but all of the other great features from the 9000 series are present.

column1: Once you properly calibrate your set be ready to be amazed.

column2: Pacific Rim and Transformers 4: Age of Extinction
column3: three of my favorite Reference movies on Blu Ray.

column1: The new OS is easy to navigate and use.
I considered both the JS9000 & 9500 but I'm not a fan of curved TV's.
I did way to many hours of research leaning towards discounted 2014 models as I'm basically done paying extra for being an early adopter of new technology.
In the end I just couldn't pull the trigger on settling for what my eyes perceived to be an inferior picture to the JS8500.
I needed a TV now and am willing to watch the price drop in the coming year.
If your considering this TV my recommendation is go for it!
I'll update this review after I get more time using this TV.
I've attached a photo of a youtube 4k video taken with my samsung S5 phone.
I purchased this TV about 2 weeks ago and I can't say enough good things about it.
The picture is so clear that it makes you wonder how you lived with 1080p beforehand.
But I will warn you it takes some time of working through all of its features before you get this picture.
If you have a Xbox One or PS4 you will see a drastic difference as well.
I play Destiny on Xbox One and it looks amazing.
One thing you will have to do with FPS or action games is switch over to game mode every time.
Without this switch you will notice a substantial lag that will make for a not so pleasant gaming experience.
Once you switch over to game mode though it looks amazing.

I did an awful lot of research before buying a TV in this price range and through all my reading I saw that Hight Dynamic Range (HDR) was extremely important to future proof your investment and this TV has it.
The other model I looked very closely at was the new Sony model in the same 55 inch set.
Both had amazing picture but the HDR coupled with the slightly better picture in my opinion I chose this model.
I know many people say there isn't much 4K content out right now and that is fairly true.
But I have watched a fair number or blu rays the past two weeks and they look stunning.
I turned on the UHD upscale and it creates a far better picture than my prior 50 inch LED 1080p TV.
One that was particularly amazing was Lucy.
The colors are so vibrant its hard to look away.
The Samsung UN65JS8500FXZA TV arrived on November 12.
They were serious flashlight issues emitting from the sides and bottom of the TV screen (see attached pictures).
This TV is an LED edge lit TV.
This seems to be a common problem with this model.
I've seen other people complain about this issue online.
I filed a support ticket at Samsung.com and attached the images showing the problem.
I also called Sumsung Support and referenced my online support ticket ID number.
<td>After speaking to several people and being disconnected once
column2: Samsung arranged to have a local authorized repair technician come to my house and replace the TV screen on November 17.

column1: I was on the phone for a total of two hours with Samsung and their agents to get the entire problem resolved.
<td>Now that the screen has been replaced
column2: the TV looks great.

column1: I am very pleased with the final result.

column2: the TV screen should have worked when purchased.

column1: I should not have to replace a brand new screen.

column2: I give 3 stars instead of 5.
it is now December 30

column1: I have owned the TV for 6 weeks now and it works flawlessly.
The best image is shown when seated directly in front of the TV.
I attached an image showing Home Alone playing on the TV.

column2: the 3D is awesome.

column1: I didn't even buy the TV for the 3D capability.
But I am so happy I did.
You can convert any television show or movie to 3D.

column2: but it does work with everything else.

column1: I am super pleased with the 3D functionality.
The UN65JS8500FXZA comes with one pair of glasses.
I bought additional open box Samsung 3D glasses online at BestBuy.com for $9.99.
Please let me know if you have any questions.
I normally look to upgrade every 2-3 years and this process is usually a very simple one - checkout the offerings from Sony & Samsung and select the best option.

column2: both those that are here and those that are arriving soon (hopefully) made this process much more involved and a bit befuddling at times.

column1: I'm still not all that sold on 4k but the best picture quality technologies are only available on 4k sets so you have to take a close look at what's available in this space.

column2: wider color gamuts
column3: nano-crystals/Triluminous displays
column4: etc. are nice features
column5: none of them would have changed my original plan for a 2014 1080P set.

column1: What did was HDR because I believe that could be a game changer.
<td>It also narrowed the search down to two Samsung models
column2: the JS8500 or JS9000
column3: and I don't think you can go wrong with either one.

column1: The 9000 is curved and has better sound but neither of those was a concern for me.
But it also has the full OCB for better future upgradeability so that was worth considering.

column2: so I would rather use the $500 difference in price along with the future evolution kit upgrade ($400+) and whatever you can sell the JS8500 for and put that towards a new TV when the time comes.
it's only been a few days but so far I am extremely happy with the JS8500.

column1: Setup was a breeze and the picture quality ranges from great to pick-your-own-superlative.
Now there are a few channels that looked better on my old TV (Samsung F6300) but they don't look that great to begin with so be prepared for a few sources that will disappoint.
I'm getting used to the remote but it is on the small side and won't be suitable for some folks.
But any of these can be easily upgraded and are not rating factors for me.
Now I'd like to mention a few setup/installation items that might save some folks a little aggravation and maybe result in more accurate reviews.

column2: I did experience one issue with this set which was some flickering/flashlighting on the bottom of the screen that was very noticeable when watching movies in letterbox format.

column1: But sometimes this is caused by the screws being over-tightened during the mfg.

column2: so I loosened the 4 bottom screws by about a 1/4 turn (one needed more) and the problem has not returned.
if you have satellite like I do (DirecTV) you should test your signal strength to make sure you don't have any issues because this can greatly impact picture quality on any set.

column1: This is easily done under the Settings menu with DTV.
You also want to make sure the cable/satellite box is configured to allow the TV to do ALL the upscaling/processing.
With DTV this means Resolutions should all be checked with Native set to ON and screen format set to original format.
<td>I would also recommend turning off all of the following on the TV
column2: at least initially - Instant On/ECO settings/Smart Security/Anti-virus.

column1: <td>These can cause various problems with streaming
column2: shutoffs
column3: etc.

column1: so try these individually after you have everything else setup/dialed in.
I know they say you shouldn't professionally calibrate it until after 100 hours so maybe this is related.
I also need to give a couple major kudos to Amazon.

column2: they double boxed the shipment which is a service that some places charge $30-75 for and others don't even offer.
they took care of me when Samsung not only extended the original sale past 6/13
column3: but then included a free soundbar or 24 TV with every purchase.

column1: Still enjoying the new TV and decided to have the set calibrated.
A lot of people have reviewed this set in detail.

column2: here's a few words about the One Connect Mini box that is included.

column1: <td>I think most people will use this TV with one or more HDMI devices -- either an A/V receiver
column2: set top box
column3: Blu-Ray player
column4: etc.

column2: I got a couple of messages about problems with the HDMI connections.

column1: I think these were due to the One Connect cable being loose.

column2: and you need to make sure it is firmly connected
column3: with a final click.

column2: I had no more such problems.

column1: I've had the Samsung UN65JS8500 for 3 months now with no problems.
Some people have been hating on the remote.
I had an issue where none of the HDMI ports were working.
<td>I thought maybe I would need a new one-connect box to fix this
column2: but Samsung support (1) checked that I had the latest software
column3: and (2) had me unplug the TV while it was ON; wait a bit
column4: then re-plug it.

column1: I bought this TV knowing the issues with blue corners.
hope this helps people looking at this TV and I am happy to answer any questions you might have as it is a big investment for most and the technology can sometimes feel intimidating to some.\
<td>Hoping I was not one of those people
column2: I ended up with that set.
the bottom left corner was not flush.

column1: Contacted Samsung and they deemed it to have physical damage from shipping and refused to repair it.
I will not be buying another Samsung set.
They will do everything possible to deny a warranty claim.

column2: and just returned it last week.

column1: (unless they were hiding with the stand.
<td>I can't believe that for a 2015 TV
column2: and for this price
column3: I would be experiencing this level of issues.

column1: <td>The Vizio M70-C3 i bought before this TV had way better backlight
column2: with only 32 active LED full array zones
column3: it out performed this samsung.

column1: <td>I really wanted to like this TV
column2: as I have a 52 Samsung 7000 series from 9 years ago on the wall
column3: and it is still a very good TV.

column1: <td>I can't believe these two tv's share the same tech for the most part
column2: aside from the smart features
column3: 3D
column4: form factor
column5: inch count and the nano crystals...I decided to go with the LG 65EG9600 to squash any of my gripes...and if that TV doesn't knock my socks off

column2: and wait a few years.
it has some drawbacks that might be significant to you
column3: and there are other televisions that are much cheaper that you might consider.

column2: this is a very good looking tv
column3: with real metal around the bezel and stand
column4: and if you care about looks
column5: this is a nice plus to have in a set.

column1: <td>Cons: this has a very reflective screen
column2: so if you have it in a room with lots of windows or light sources
column3: be aware that you will see them reflected in the screen.

column2: as the screen can get very bright
column3: but if you are bothered by this be aware.

column2: this set looks weak when you move off axis
column3: worse than others I've had.

column1: <td>so if you have a large room where people will be seated far off to the side
column2: be aware
column3: the screen gets very washed out unless you sit in front of it.

column2: since this is edge lit instead of back lit
column3: black levels will not be as dark as with a back lit screen.

column2: but not quite as good as my Vizio that is back lit.
overall for me this was a good purchase
column3: but there are definitely drawbacks that might be important enough for you to not consider this.

column2: the pros outweigh the cons.
the Vizio M series is much cheaper than this
column3: 4k and full array back lit
column4: with good blacks and other advantages as well.

column1: I would check that out for sure and decide which is best for your preferences.
IMO comparable Sony's or LG's are not worth considering.
My 65 has a very obvious lighting glowing defect in the lower left and lower right corners when viewing light-colored content regardless of source.
Looks like many other users are reporting the same thing with recently purchased TVs.
Check out the Official JS8500 thread on AVSForum for a bunch of customer photos that highlight the issue.
I'm boxing it back up for a return.
Let me start by saying that this TV is the best TV I have ever had.
The picture quality is beyond what I expected!!!
<td>I pick this up from Best Buy since they had there Black Friday prices available now
column2: same as Amazon has it currently.

column1: <td>I can't tell you how amazed I am with TV
column2: the black levels are great for Samsung's entry level of the SUHD brand.

column1: <td>I originally planed on getting the LG 65UF8600
column2: but I seen that LG has a lot of back light bleeding issues
column3: and doing more research
column4: I found that it is not to future proof or HDR compatible.

column2: I'm a huge LG fan
column3: my last TV before this was an 55inch LG 1080p
column4: with this TV I have no back lighting issues.

column1: <td>I have only watched one 3D movie so far (Gravity)
column2: it looked amazing.

column1: <td>I am mad that Samsung only decided to provide one single pair of 3D glasses
column2: provided the amount of money we are spending ($2
column4: they could at least spare another 15 or 20 bucks and provide one more pair
column5: guess I'll be watching by myself until I get some more!!!!

column1: I have have two Monster Black Platinum HDMI cables connected.
<td>One to my 2014 Samsung BD-F7500 4K Up-scaling 3D Blu-Ray player
column2: and the other to my XBox One.
I highly recommend getting them
column3: I had these for about a year now connected to my 1080p TV
column4: and they have done wonders for the picture on that set.

column1: <td>The cables are about a $100 a pop (plus tax)
column2: and they are worth it.

column1: <td>I have one with the LED indicator ($10 more)
column2: which tells me when the signal is in SD
column3: HD
column4: or 4K.

column1: <td>I've done some calibration on my own with this TV
column2: it doesn't need to much tuning though.

column1: The one connect box died just over a month after purchase.
It will take samsung 5-15 business day to have a replacement box shipped to me.
<td>If you were to order this tv directly through samsung's website
column2: it'll ship w/in 1-3 business days
column3: but the part that's essential to the tvs functionality takes anywhere from 5-15 business days?

column1: <td>This wouldn't be an issue if the tv had at least one hdmi input on the tv
column2: but it doesn't so you're at the mercy of the one connect box.

column1: <td>If it fails then your brand new
column2: expensive tv is useless until a replacement box is shipped to you.

column1: like to be specific when I write reviews here as too often the reviews of multiple models/products get blended together.
This review is for the Samsung UN24H4000 24-Inch 720p 60Hz LED TV; Amazon ASIN: B00KSBBGA4.
I have only used this TV for one day and at this time only have it connected to an older digital cable box via a coax connection.
I did use the Component connections for a DVD player and the picture quality is excellent.
I will have a Mini Tivo box installed early next week and following that will have an HDMI cable tv connection.
I will update my review following that.
I now have this TV connected to a Tivo Mini and the picture quality is totally excellent.
If you are concerned about 720 vs 1080 I say don't worry.
I have a four-year-old Visio 22 1080 TV in another location and the picture from this Samsung with 720 is just as good if not better.
All of the ports are on a squarish panel on the rear of the TV and all face to the rear.
<td>I point this out because if you plan on using a USB device (such as thumb drive) to view media
column2: you may want to obtain a USB extension cable
column3: because if you have the TV against a wall
column4: or in an enclosed cabinet like I do
column5: the rear panel may not be easily accessible.

column1: (Note that a USB extension cable is NOT the same thing as a standard USB cable.)
Another reason I point this out is the Amazon photos for this product clearly show a side panel with HDMI and USB ports.
I am certain that the photos come from Samsung as the same photos are shown at BestBuy.Com and Beach Audio.
Both the shipping carton and the product label on the rear of the TV clearly identify this TV as a UN24H4000 model.
It appears that Samsung has revised the panel configuration of this model to match the separate UN24H4500 model.

column2: with the exception of a great deal of frustration mounting the TV to its base.

column1: This model comes with three documents: A Setup Guide; a Quick tart Guide; and a User Manual.
<td>Even the User Manual is a fold-out
column2: is 16 by 22 in size when opened
column3: printed on both sides
column4: and printed in tiny print.
